But unlike many places in the world where traditional culture exists only to entertain tourists, in Bali a calendar rich with religious festivals, ceremonies, cremations, and parades, is woven into the daily tapestry of life here, and has been since the seventh century when travelers from India brought Hinduism to this small island.
(Soundbite of music)
With or without tourists, each day, Balinese reverently put out delicate offerings of rice and flowers to protect their homes, cars, and dangerous intersections.
An elaborate moon festival each month, brings long lines of Balinese to the thousands of temples that dot Bali's towns and rice terraced countryside.
Priests dressed all in white, men and women from the Brahmin caste, ring bells, sprinkle water, and press wet rice on the foreheads of worshippers.
(Soundbite of bell ringing)
(Soundbite of music)
During Nyepi, Bali's lunar new year, celebrated each spring, the island erupts in bright colors and clanging music.
(Soundbite of music)
All work stops, as people parade to the seashore, accompanied by their village gamelan bands; composed of all manner of percussion instruments.
Young and old join together as teenage boys trade in their low-slung jeans and t-shirts, for the men's traditional double sarongs and fabric hats.
Women bring carefully arranged offerings of fruit, balanced on their heads, their colorful batik sarongs tied with a scarf around their waist to separate their higher and lower selves.
(Soundbite of music)
Some of the demons project a humorous local flare, including one wearing a pair of flip-flop sandals.
And, my personal favorite, a demon with knees bent and arms extended riding a surfboard.
(Soundbite of music)
After days of bold communal celebration, the solitude and quiet of Nyepi day comes as a surprise.
No one, and I mean no one, on the island is permitted to leave home for 24 hours as the Balinese people engage in prayer and quiet meditation.
And the struggling economy, desperate for tourists, does not alter tradition.
